top_categories.workout_context: Tour de Nebraska’s 250-mile distance demands power production deep into fatigue — the defining challenge of ultra-distance gravel.
At 250 miles, Tour de Nebraska rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.

Tour de Nebraska’s mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel adventure includes single-lane maintenance roads, fresh gravel, and minimum maintenance roads (mmr) demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Tour de Nebraska isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Every session at Tour de Nebraska intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.

Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Tour de Nebraska’s mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel adventure includes single-lane maintenance roads, fresh gravel, and minimum maintenance roads (mmr) delivers on race day.
Tour de Nebraska rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Tour de Nebraska when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.

Tempo is the race-day intensity of Tour de Nebraska. Harder than Z2, easier than threshold — the pace you’ll hold for hours on mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel adventure includes single-lane maintenance roads, fresh gravel, and minimum maintenance roads (mmr).
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Tour de Nebraska. Make this intensity feel like home.

Tour de Nebraska’s mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel adventure includes single-lane maintenance roads, fresh gravel, and minimum maintenance roads (mmr) and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Tour de Nebraska — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.

race_overlay.nutrition: Ultra-distance fueling for 250 miles: 80–100g carbs/hour from mile 1 — don’t wait until you’re hungry. Practice your exact race-day nutrition in every long training ride. Carry backup calories. 250 miles burns 8,000–12,000+ calories — you cannot replace them all, but you must try.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Tour de Nebraska requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel adventure includes single-lane maintenance roads, fresh gravel, and minimum maintenance roads (mmr) to build confidence.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, HVLI Extended, and Gravel Specific to prepare you for 250 miles of mix of paved roads and gravel; optional gravel adventure includes single-lane maintenance roads, fresh gravel, and minimum maintenance roads (mmr) in Southwest Nebraska (Curtis, Elwood, Cambridge, McCook).
